com.ccc.deeplearning.berkeley

Class CounterMap<K,V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ccc.deeplearning.berkeley.CounterMap<K,V>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    public class CounterMap<K,V>
extends Object
implements Serializable
    Maintains counts of (key, value) pairs. The map is structured so that for every key, one can get a counter over values. Example usage: keys might be words with values being POS tags, and the count being the number of occurences of that word/tag pair. The sub-counters returned by getCounter(word) would be count distributions over tags for that word.
    Author:
    Dan Klein
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • getCount

        public double getCount(K key,
              V value)
        Gets the count of the given (key, value) entry, or zero if that entry is not present. Does not create any objects.

      • getCounter

        public Counter<V> getCounter(K key)
        Gets the sub-counter for the given key. If there is none, a counter is created for that key, and installed in the CounterMap. You can, for example, add to the returned empty counter directly (though you shouldn't). This is so whether the key is present or not, modifying the returned counter has the same effect (but don't do it).

      • incrementAll

        public void incrementAll(Map<K,V> map,
                double count)

        public double getCount(K key)
        Gets the total count of the given key, or zero if that key is not present. Does not create any objects.

      • totalCount

        public double totalCount()
        Returns the total of all counts in sub-counters. This implementation is linear; it recalculates the total each time.

      • totalSize

        public int totalSize()
        Returns the total number of (key, value) entries in the CounterMap (not their total counts).

      • size

        public int size()
        The number of keys in this CounterMap (not the number of key-value entries -- use totalSize() for that)

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        True if there are no entries in the CounterMap (false does not mean totalCount > 0)

      • argMax

        public Pair<K,V> argMax()
        Finds the key with maximum count. This is a linear operation, and ties are broken arbitrarily.
        Returns:
        a key with minumum count
